entry.title: Re: different e-mail adresses for sending purchase order...
entry.content:
Maintain one additional mail address and misuse field remark. e.g. BA (Bestelladresse) and GS (Gutschrift) 

MM-LIV Consignment settlements or ERS credit notes are always sent to the default mail address (Is hard coded) 
The GS Address should be marked as default address

Implement BADI BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL - IF_BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL~CHANGE_RECIPIENTS

DATA lv_smtp_addr TYPE ad_smtpadr.

SELECT SINGLE a~smtp_addr 
    INTO lv_smtp_addr
  FROM adr6 AS a INNER JOIN adrt AS b ON a~addrnumber = b~addrnumber AND
                                                                                    a~persnumber = b~persnumber AND
                                                                                    a~date_from = b~date_from AND
                                                                                    a~consnumber = b~consnumber
                                   INNER JOIN lfa1 AS c ON b~addrnumber = c~adrnr
WHERE c~lifnr = im_nast_entry-parnr AND b~remark = 'BA' AND b~comm_type = 'INT'. 

IF sy-subrc = 0.
    CLEAR cht_to_recipient_list. 
    APPEND lv_smtp_addr TO cht_to_recipient_list.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Leveraging SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026: A Migration Path to SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

Background

Following SAP’s announcement of the upcoming SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 release, many customers are seeking clarity on how this new version differs from the existing SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA and what actions they should take today to prepare.

SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 represents the next evolution of SAP’s governance, risk, and compliance portfolio, offering enhanced capabilities and long-term support. While the new release is not yet available, customers can already take important steps to simplify their current GRC landscape and position themselves for a smoother upgrade when SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 becomes available.

This blog outlines why preparing now on SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA matters, what benefits customers can expect from SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026, and how SAP consulting services can support this journey.

 

Why SAP GRC for S/4HANA Now?

The move to SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA is a preparatory and consolidation step, not something customers should delay until SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 is released.

Today, many customers run SAP GRC components, UI Data Protection, and Assurance & Compliance solutions across multiple systems or instances, sometimes even outside of SAP S/4HANA. Consolidating these capabilities into a single SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA instance enables customers to:

  • Simplify their GRC architecture and reduce operational and technical complexity
  • Be technically ready for a future upgrade to SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026

Importantly, this consolidation effort often requires significant planning and execution time, which is why starting early is critical.

Objectives

The primary goals of this paper are to:

  • Highlight the advantages of migrating to SAP GRC for S/4HANA.
  • Explain how the SAP GRC for S/4HANA version integrates multiple solutions.
  • Introduce SAP consulting services as a comprehensive solution for a seamless migration.

Scope

This blog highlights the benefits of migrating to SAP GRC for S/4HANA, especially for customers using:

  • SAP Access Control
  • SAP Process Control
  • SAP Risk Management
  • SAP Assurance and Compliance applications (Audit Management, Business Integrity Screening, Business Partner Screening, Tax Compliance)
  • UI Data Protection Masking and UI Data Protection Logging

Moving these solutions into a single SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA instance creates a clean and stable foundation for future innovation and upgrades.

Benefits of SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026

Enhanced Compliance and Efficiency

The SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version introduces upcoming innovations designed to enhance compliance and streamline processes in which some key benefits include:

  • AI Integration: Use of AI for advanced risk detection and reporting.
  • Enhanced User Interface (UI): Improved user experience with a more intuitive interface.
  • Improved Reporting: Enhanced reporting capabilities for better visualization, disclosure and compliance management.

Integrated Solutions

One of the standout features of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version is its ability to combine multiple solutions into a unified platform. This includes:

  • GRC Core Solutions: Access Control, Process Control, and Risk Management.
  • Assurance and Compliance Solutions: Audit Management, Business Integrity Screening, and Tax Compliance.
  • UI Data Protection: Masking, and Logging.

By integrating these solutions, organizations can benefit from:

  • Centralized Data Management: A unified platform for comprehensive data management and reporting.
  • Seamless Workflows: Improved coordination between different GRC functions.
  • Reduced Complexity: Simplified deployment and maintenance of GRC solutions.

Migration Strategy

Consulting Services

To ensure a seamless migration, SAP offers comprehensive consulting services. Our expert team can guide you through every step of the process, providing tailored solutions to meet your specific needs. Prepare today and migrate confidently later.

Key services include:

  • Assessment and Planning: Evaluate your current deployment and develop a detailed migration plan.
  • Migration execution: Our consulting team has both tools and expertise to perform wide range of migration tasks, from simplest to the most complex.
  • Technical Support: Provide hands-on technical assistance during the migration.
  • Post-Migration Support: Ensure a smooth transition and address any post-migration issues.

Customized Solutions

SAP's consulting services can be tailored to your organization's unique requirements, ensuring that the migration aligns with your business objectives and technical environment. Our experts will work closely with you to:

  • Optimize Workflows: Streamline GRC processes to improve efficiency.
  • Enhance Compliance: Ensure that your organization meets all regulatory requirements.
  • Maximize ROI: Leverage the full potential of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version to drive business value.

Conclusion

Summary

Preparing for SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 starts today. By consolidating on SAP GRC for SAP S/4HANA, customers can simplify their GRC landscape, reduce complexity, and significantly lower the risk and effort of a future upgrade. SAP consulting services provide the guidance and expertise needed to make this transition efficient and well-controlled.

Implications

Successful migration to the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 version will enhance your organization's compliance efforts, improve system performance, and ensure long-term support and regulatory compliance. Engaging with SAP's consulting services will make this process efficient and reliable.

Details and Benefits of SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026

  • AI Integration improves risk detection and reporting.
  • Enhanced UI offers a more intuitive user experience.
  • Improved Reporting bolsters visualization and compliance management.
  • Integrated Solutions unify GRC Core and Assurance functions, promoting centralized data management, seamless workflows, and reduced complexity.

Additionally, for a deeper dive into the product management session and a preview of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026 solution, follow this link.

Contact Us

To learn more about the migration to SAP GRC for S/4HANA and engage with our consulting services, please contact us at:

  • Email: sap_dmlt_gce@sap.com

Stay tuned for announcements about upcoming SAP and partner webinars!

entry.title: Catch Weight Management in Receiving Process
entry.content:
Hi 

I have set up Catch Weight Management in my On Prem S/HANA box 2022 release 107.

I have all configuration and master data in place which is allowing me to manage parallel units of measure in handling units and storage bins.

I have only been able to capture the valuation quantity during packing of my inbound delivery in PRDI. Once the valuation quantity is measured against each HU am I able to goods receipt and create putaway tasks for my handling units.

My WPT has the field "Valuation Quantity Input Required for WT Confirmation" (/SCWM/T333-CWMEAS) checked.

I have read note 3297858 which advises of a restriction in RFUI processing for catch weight products, the resolution proposes to use RF Putaway. I have tried confirming my putaway WT in PTHUSI but there is nothing appearing for capturing the valuation quantity.

I have seen a YouTube video of an RFUI screen being able to capture this information but I'm not sure if it has been developed or if it is a standard screen.

Does anyone know if there is a way of being able to record valuation quantities in RFUI for Catch Weight products in Embedded EWM without a new Catch Weight screen being development?

Thanks in advance 

Mike

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - How to retrieve currency code...
entry.content:
Hi byd,

Instead of the table, do you have a CDS View you think would work?

In the public cloud, the tables are not exposed, you need to work through CDS View

For example would I_Currency or I_CurrencyStdVH work for you? (I_Currency references the table you mention).

You can review the cds views in the View Browser app.

If so, you can create a custom CDS View based on the CDS View you want to expose. Then expose the Custom CDS View as an ODATA Service.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/e30de6eae4d24d70b65996ac8ff88848.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

 

Thank you
Jerry

entry.title: Re: SAP Business Data Cloud Certification (C_BCBDC): The Ultimate Guide to Passing SAP’s New AI Scen
entry.content: I retook the exam yesterday afternoon. Everything was going well, I was answering the questions and receiving AI feedback, and I felt motivated. With 40 minutes remaining, she said she had to go and only had two more minutes, then asked the last question. It was about steps, so I checked my notes and responded. She said, “Well, that was a lot for me,” asked for my email, and said, “I will send you an email to continue with the remaining questions.” I thought that was the final question. However, she left with 38 minutes remaining, and the score and feedback stayed in “processing” for those 38 minutes until time ran out. I then received a failure message with no score. I created a case with SAP yesterday for this situation.

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: 2026 starts with SAP Champions posts, AI tips and survey to give your opinion!
entry.content:
Happy New Year!  

Our Community Voice is back, and we are more than happy to be present for our SAP Community in 2026. We hope our members got to enjoy some relaxing and festive times and that you are feeling rested and prepared to start this year with the right attitude. 2026 is going to be full of amazing moments and opportunities to keep learning, connecting, and growing our community all over the world. 

To start the year right, we collected some of the great highlights that have already been happening in the first two weeks of January. Very insightful blog posts about new features and recommendations for the best use of SAP technologies, a nice opportunity to explore what is new on our platform, and a look at how our SAP Mentors and Champions have been collaborating within the SAP Community, plus all the great events coming this year! 

Let’s dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts 

SAP Integration Suite New Features Released at the End of 2025 

In Q4 of 2025, SAP Integration Suite delivered great new features, such as AI-powered recommendations that simplify troubleshooting and streamlined connectivity with top platforms like Amazon Kinesis and Box. SAP´s Maiara Ellwanger recently posted a blog post covering the details of these innovations, along with information on new dataspace integration packages, data center availability in new locations, event-driven integrations, B2B interchanges in Trading Partner Management, and new features in Process Integration. Make sure to check out her blog post, as it includes all the details you need to boost your operational efficiency. 

Read Maiara Ellwanger Blog Post here 

Synchronizing BTP Accounts into SAP LeanIX 

One of the main pillars of IT landscape expansion is maintaining transparency and governance. It is important not only to know how systems are connected, but also to understand what exists, why it exists, who owns it, and how it fits into the overall enterprise architecture. SAP Champion Punith Oswal, explains in his latest blog post how LeanIX plays a crucial role with Enterprise Architecture Management, considering that LeanIX focuses heavily on data-driven architecture decisions, ensuring that architecture is not just diagrams, but living documentation. If you want to have a full explanation on how the SAP BTP accounts works in LeanIX and the details on the process (including very helpful images, to make your life even easier finding the configurations), this content is a must read.  

Read Punith Oswall Blog Post here 

Tips on How to Start 2026 with SAP´s AI offer 

Generative AI is more omnipresent than ever in daily lives, and according to SAP´s Leo Irudayam the key to successful AI adoption is a useful case, with the right technology and people. In his blog post, he makes AI tools tangible and understandable by sketching an AI-assisted process of vehicle onboarding, showing how it can be automated by leveraging different AI tools offered by SAP within the Business AI portfolio. Leo also explores SAP´s own foundational model RPT-1 and agentic tasks with Joule Studio. He concludes with a reminder that SAP Document AI is a leader in document processing with inbound and outbound channels, and SAP AI Core a powerful AI orchestration service at low costs each. 

Read Leo Irudayam Blog Post here 

Different approach: UI5 Library Use on BTP by Bundling Libraries at Build Time 

SAP Champion Mio Yasutake published a great blog post presenting valuable tools for simplifying UI5 Library use on BTP, considering two different approaches (with and without CDM) and the benefits and limitations of deploying libraries independently. The highlight of her post is an alternative approach: Bundling the Library at Build time. She explains that the main advantage of this approach are the simpler application configuration and the removal of dependencies on resources defined by the library, such as destinations or HTML5 app host service instances. Mio provides a detailed step-by-step guide with images and all the necessary code. We highly recommend checking it out! 

Read here Mio Yasutake Blog Post here 

Community News 

Tell us what you think and win a virtual meet and greet with Josh Bentley 

We want to hear what you think! SAP Community Advocate Mynyna Chau, recently opened a survey (click here to participate), so our Community Team knows your thoughts, needs and preferences. This is our way to tailor our future community initiatives accordingly, but also because we believe that your input makes a difference. The survey takes just a few minutes of your time and can be completed from your smartphone or computer. Once the survey concludes, we will carefully analyze the results and share a report summary with you.  

And as a token of our appreciation, helping us spread the word enters you into a draw to win a virtual meet & greet with Josh Bentley, head of SAP Community! All you need to do is share the survey link / QR-Code in your social media and comment on Mynyna´s Blog Post here with a link to your social media post that shows how you helped spread the word.  

Hobbies Series: Passion for Writing

The holiday season can be a wonderful opportunity to relax and be available for activities that are often left behind during normal routines. These breaks also allow us to discover hobbies that keep our minds engaged with things we love. At the beginning of this month, SAP Community members shared insights into their favorite activities as part of our Hobbies Series. SAP´s Hakan Haslaman wrote about his passion for writing (blog post here), describing it to shape his experiences and thoughts, whether from everyday life or situations far outside his comfort zone. He shared valuable insights into writing and the topics he enjoys most. He concludes by explaining that in his work in Support, two things are constant: complexity and humanity. And writing and coaching helps him to connect both.  

Events 

Reminder of SAP ALM Summit North America 2026 

As we have previously mentioned before, we would like to remind everyone about the upcoming SAP ALM Summit North America 2026. This event is the chance to boost your ALM value by learning from real-life customer experiences. Expand your knowledge through hands-on labs and attending expert-led sessions.  Some of the amazing speakers that will be presenting at the event are Tim Steuer - VP Customer Communications & Relations SAP SE, Sören Ruder- Head of Customer Experience & Solutions (CXS) SAP SE, Joshua Greenbaum- Principal of Enterprise Applications Consulting EAC and Todd Crandall- Head of Customer Services & Delivery SAP North America. Make sure to register for the event here: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026.  

This year Upcoming Events  

Time flies, and we are already in the middle of January 2026. It is time to organize yourself and book all the great events you cannot miss this year. Check out the list below to see the events already scheduled for 2026:  

  • 20 of January: SAP CodeJam - Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Bielefeld, Germa...  
  • 21 of January: SAP CodeJam - Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India )  
  • 22 of January: SAP CodeJam ABAP: SAP BTP, ABAP Environment & RAP ( Hyderabad, India )  
  • 23 of January: SAP Stammtisch Wroclaw - January Edition! (Registration is closed)  
  • 29 of January: SAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India)  
  • 09 of February: Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Pune, India)  
  • 26 of February:  Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium)  
  • 14 of March: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 – Brasil  
  • 17 of March: SAP TALK WOMEN CWB 2026- Curitiba, Brasil  
  • 14 - 16 of April: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026- Pennsylvania, United States 
  • 26 of September: SAP Inside Track Porto 2026 - Portugal  
  • 31 of October: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026- Brasil

entry.title: Re: eInvoicing Direct Debit SEPA Mandate #COE#SW01
entry.content:
This is the reply I got from the SAP ticket.

We would like to confirm that in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the behavior you are is expected and system-standard.

When a Billing Document (Debit Memo) is created using the Billing Document Request Excel upload, the SEPA Mandate Reference is not populated. This is because the Excel upload process creates billing documents without using the Sales and Distribution (SD) document flow, and therefore SD copy control logic is not executed. The SEPA Mandate Reference is derived only when billing documents are created from SD documents such as Sales Orders or Contracts.

As a result:

  • The standard Excel upload template does not include a field for SEPA Mandate Reference
  • The system has no source document from which to derive the mandate
  • The mandate reference therefore remains empty and is not passed to the Belgium e-invoice

This is a current functional limitation in S/4HANA Public Cloud, not a tenant-specific restriction.

When billing documents are created via:

  • Sales Order → Billing, or
  • Contract → Billing

the SEPA Mandate Reference is correctly derived and passed through to the Belgium e-invoice (Peppol XML).

For Belgium SEPA Direct Debit scenarios, SAP recommends using SD-based billing processes to ensure full SEPA and e-invoicing compliance. Upload-based billing (Excel Billing Document Requests) should be avoided for customers requiring SEPA mandates.

SAP is aware of this functional gap. Therefore, now we redirect this incident to a dedicated team and request for a possible support and workaround. 

Thank you for your patience and regards,
EU Peppol Development Team

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
@evelyn_barbosa As per the location you are using HR_F_MMREF_1.
You need to fill with your company information.
Go to SM30, select V_T51T3 and forms HR_F_MMREF_1.

You can update fields:
10    HR_F_MMREF_1    2    222        Employer Contact Name                27    No special preparation    W-2 Electronic filing (EFW2 Format)    RE- Employer Record
10    HR_F_MMREF_1    2    249        Employer Contact Phone Number                15    No special preparation    W-2 Electronic filing (EFW2 Format)    RE- Employer Record
10    HR_F_MMREF_1    2    279        Employer Contact E-Mail                40    No special preparation    W-2 Electronic filing (EFW2 Format)    RE- Employer Record

Please, add this information from your company and update the required fields. As this is different from each company. 

Kind regards,
Graziela

entry.title: Re: How to bring your ABAP custom code to SAP BTP ABAP Environment
entry.content:
Hi David @dnguyen_31 ,

the recommended approach ("how") is as described in this blog. I would recommend to check this add-on for cloud readiness like described here: https://blogs.sap.com/2018/10/02/how-to-check-your-custom-abap-code-for-sap-cloud-platform-abap-environment/ and see how many issues you get and if it would be manageble to resolve them without having to reimplement the whole add-on code. Generally, if the add-on tightly coupled with the SAP IS-U component, it is not recommendable to outsource it to BTP ABAP environment (e.g. if the data of SAP IS-U is changed jointly, or frequent SQL access to SAP IS-U is used, reading high data volume from SAP IS-U tables, calling many SAP IS-U APIs which are not publicly released....).

Kind Regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Re: #CoE#LYNCH How do I transport the GL master change in...
entry.content:
Hi, 

 

When using the Manage G/L Account Master Data app in a three-system landscape (Development → Test → Production), the system prompts you to assign a transport request upon making changes.
You may:

  • Select the last-used transport,

  • Choose an existing open transport, or

  • Create a new transport request.

During the same app session, the system will not prompt you again for a transport. A new prompt will only appear if you close and reopen the app.

For further details, please refer to SAP Help documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/34428754dccbe85ee10000000a44176d.html?locale=en-US

 

In a three-system landscape, all G/L account master data changes must be performed in the Development system.

To perform changes, you must have the appropriate business roles and catalogs:

  • Configuration Experts require business catalogs delivered with the
    Configuration Expert – Business Process Configuration role
    (SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT).

  • Expert Accounting Users require business catalogs delivered with the
    General Ledger Accountant role
    (SAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT), allowing limited maintenance via specific Fiori apps.

An open transport request is mandatory to save changes, following the standard SAP transport process.

 

Changes are made as follows in the 3-system landscape:

The changes are available in your development system. From there, the changes are transported to your test system and then to your production system. In your test and production systems, G/L account master data is read only.

In your test system and then to your production system you can view the accounts. When additional G/L account master data changes are needed, the necessary changes are done in the development system. These changes are then transported to your test system and then to your production system, following the standard transport process.

Access this link for more information: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/e8b6fd604f244e4bb89db8bd6c6c98ca.html?locale=en-US

 

To get an overview of how to display the change logs of the customizing transports that you've previously imported you can use Import Collection app.

The change logs of the customizing transports may contain, for example, information on the changes that were made in customizing, the activity and the object, the log date and time, the operation.

For more information check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/8dcf6d20fb21428a9e1c173453de162d.html?locale=en-US

 

 

 

For more information about the standard process for transporting changes in a 3-system landscape, see Importing a Customizing Collection (3SL).

 

Best regards, 

Elena P.

entry.content:
Hello Experts

I am using the Destination service in SAP BTP, and the destination is consumed by an SAP CAP application (Node.js).

Currently, the destination is defined in mta.yaml, and for an on-premise system (via Cloud Connector) it requires BasicAuthentication.

I want to avoid hardcoding credentials (user/password) in mta.yaml.

What is the recommended and secure way to manage credentials for destinations used by CAP applications?

Any guidance or best practices for production scenarios would be appreciated.

- name: <name>-destination
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  requires:
    - name: srv-api
  parameters:
    service: destination
    service-plan: lite
    config:
      HTML5Runtime_enabled: true
      init_data:
        instance:
          destinations:
            - Name: <name>-srv
              URL: ~{srv-api/srv-url}
              Authentication: NoAuthentication
              Type: HTTP
              ProxyType: Internet
              HTML5.ForwardAuthToken: true
              HTML5.DynamicDestination: true
              HTML5.Timeout: 600000

            - Name: ui5
              Authentication: NoAuthentication
              ProxyType: Internet
              Type: HTTP
              URL: https://ui5.sap.com

            - Name: S4_TECH
              URL: http://<ON_PREMISE_HOST>:<PORT>
              Type: HTTP
              ProxyType: OnPremise
              Authentication: BasicAuthentication
              User: "<TECH_USER>"
              Password: "<REDACTED>"
              sap-client: "<CLIENT>"
              CloudConnectorLocationId: "<LOCATION_ID>"
              Description: "Technical destination for nightly sync"
          existing_destinations_policy: update

entry.title: Re: How to Send Internal Buyer Email Notification on Good...
entry.content:
Hi Viktor,

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are multiple supported options to implement internal email notifications to the buyer when a Goods Receipt (GR) is posted for a Purchase Order. The choice depends on how you want to model the requirement and how much flexibility you need.

 

Option 1: Situation Handling – Extended Framework

SAP S/4HANA Cloud provides an extended framework for Situation Handling, which allows you to create custom situation use cases based on specific business objects and events.

Using this framework, you can:

  • Model your own situation objects
  • Define events that trigger situations (for example, based on GR-related data)
  • Configure situation pages, including navigation and follow-up actions
  • Define recipients and notification channels, including email

The extended framework is configured using the following apps:

  • Manage Situation Objects: with this app, you can model business objects that enable Situation Handling

Follow the link for instructions:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/d973eb6d464d4dce84f354b9668ef43c.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Manage Situation Scenarios: with this app you can model your own situation scenarios for extended object-based situations.

Follow the link for instructions:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/dfac958be2af4ce79589e8a3eaff88d6.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Manage Situation Types – Extended: with this app you create situation templates and types that can be used in the extended framework for Situation Handling

Follow the link for instructions:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/45d60edcf02d409c87076f92

 

Email notifications for your Situation Handling

To enable email notifications for your Situation Handling using the extended framework in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, please follow these steps.

  • Users have Enabled Email Notifications: Users must activate the email notification option in their Fiori Launchpad (user settings profile → notifications → enable notification email).
  • Define recipients under the Recipients tab in Manage Situation Types – Extended. Assign users, teams, or responsibility roles with valid email addresses.
  • Verify that the email notification channel is correctly configured and active in your system. 
  • If needed, customise the notification email format in the Maintain Email Templates app

Below are SAP Community examples that illustrate how to create and adapt your own custom situation types:

  • Custom Situation Handling example
    https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/custom-situation-handling-in-quality-management-get-notified-when-an/ba-p/14277147
  • Custom Situation Cases – Configure Your Own Use Cases
    https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/custom-situation-cases-configure-your-own-use-cases-1-6/ba-p/13526769
  • How to Start with Custom Situations – High-Level Design
    https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-start-with-custom-situations-high-level-design-of-the-use-case-1-4/ba-p/13578044

 

Option 2: Output Management / Output Parameter Determination for Goods Movement

Another supported approach is to use Output Management for Goods Movement, which allows you to trigger email outputs when a GR is posted.

With this approach, you configure output rules so that when a goods movement (for example, movement type 101 – GR for PO) is posted, the system:

  • Creates an output item
  • Sends it via EMAIL to the relevant internal recipient (buyer)

High-level configuration steps

  • Make sure email channel is enabled/available in your tenant (communication + email setup, sender domain, etc., depending on your landscape). 
  • Make sure the buyer/user has a maintained email address in the user master (so the system can actually send to them).
  • Open Output Parameter Determination (OPD) app
  1. Select business document Goods Movement
  2. Create a rule for the relevant GR scenario
  3. Choose EMAIL as the output channel
  4. Maintain recipient determination so it goes to the internal buyer (commonly derived from PO responsibility such as purchasing group/buyer, depending on what fields are available in the rule context

To test the output management, Post a GR (e.g., via Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document app) and confirm an output item is created and sent. 

Relevant SAP documentation with instractions:

  • Output Parameter Determination – Goods Movement
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/b7f02d1514ff4a44b144ea214556fdaf.html
  • Best Practices: Set Up Output Parameter Determination for Goods Movement
    https://help.sap.com/docs/s4hana-best-practices/setting-up-subcontracting-with-sap-business-network-5i2-ef2a4e332ba0803bdfb38670365f8aa7/set-up-output-parameter-determination-for-goods-movement
  • Email configuration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/c9b98e682223453b9185d11de90670ac.html

 

Both Situation Handling (Extended) and Output Management for Goods Movement are supported options in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for implementing GR-related email notifications.

Depending on the desired behavior, flexibility, and notification design, you can choose the approach that best fits your business scenario and adopt it accordingly.

 

Best regards,

Elena P.

entry.title: Re: In rebase processing, Units of measure cannot be enab...
entry.content:
Hi, 

 

Units of Measure (UoMs) are language-dependent customizing objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

While the UoM key is stored in table T006, the corresponding language-dependent descriptions are maintained in table T006A. During Update Business Configuration (CBC activation / rebase), the system performs validation checks in the logon language of the user executing the activation.

 

The affected UoMs exist in the system. However, the language-dependent texts are not maintained in the logon language of the user activating the Business Configuration Set (for example, EN).

Some error messages appear in Chinese (ZH), which might indicate that the UoMs may have been created or imported while the system or user logon language was Chinese, or the UoM texts were never maintained for English (EN).

When CBC attempts to activate customizing object CUNI, the system validates the UoM texts in table T006A for the current logon language. If the corresponding entries are missing, the validation fails and the activation is aborted with errors.

 

Check  UoM Texts in the required language

  1. Navigate to Define Units of Measure (CBC / relevant SSCUI).
  2. For each affected UoM:
    • Maintain the description text in EN (or in the logon language of the user performing the CBC activation).
  3. Save the changes.
  4. Re-run Update Business Configuration.

 

Ensure that UoM texts are maintained in the logon language of the user responsible for activating Business Configuration Sets.

 

Best regards, 

Elena P.

entry.title: Calculation of PIRS does not take into account sales orders.
entry.content:
Good day,
I have the following scenario: my client requires that some sales orders not be taken into account when performing Mass Maintenance.

This is what I've done, but it hasn't worked.

1. I created my order and in the Procurement window I selected CN, I've also tried to assign the CN value at the header level, but I can't find it. Is this per position? There's no option per header, since my order is for 300 lines and the client doesn't want to change it line by line.

2.When I access the details of the PIRS maintainer, in the sales column I see an increase, and this shouldn't be happening, or at least that's what I want to prevent.

 

3.Therefore, when I run Mass Maintenance, it is taking the sales order and summing and averaging the quantity, also to prevent it from being included in the MRP.

Attached is an image of the PIRS result before and after creating the sales order.

entry.title: How to pass filters between different stories in SAC
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am currently building several SAC stories, which include an overview story (Story A) and multiple sub-stories (Story B, Story C, and Story D). All these stories share 5 identical filters.

In Story A, I have configured 5 input controls and use the NavigationUtils.openStory script to pass the selected filter values from Story A to Stories B, C, and D. Conversely, I have added hyperlinked buttons in Stories B, C, and D to allow users to jump back to Story A.

Here is the typical user workflow: First, users access Story A, set the required filter values, and then use NavigationUtils.openStory to navigate to the other sub-stories. This script works perfectly well—it automatically creates corresponding story filters in the target sub-stories and passes the selected filter values accurately.

However, a usability issue arises when users jump back to Story A via the hyperlinked buttons: the previously selected filter values in Story A are lost, and the story reverts to its default filter settings configured during the design phase.

I am wondering if there is a more optimized way to design these stories to enhance the overall user experience.

(If I use NavigationUtils.openStory to jump back to Story A, I think it will recreates story filters for Story A, and then I will lose the possibility to select from different filter values and that is not good.)

Any tips or insights would be appreciated! Thank you in advance!

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
@DianaRoesner  Hi Diana,
Hope you are doing well

I recently attempted the SAP Certified SAP Sucessfactor Employee center Core and position management certification. This was my first SAP exam and was going to start my SAP career.

However, during the exam I unexpectedly encountered the new Scenario-Based Assessment format. There was no clear indication in the learning journey or preparation materials that the exam format had fundamentally changed from a knowledge-based assessment to an interactive, scenario-driven evaluation.

During the assessment, I was unclear about the expected interaction style  whether I should ask clarifying questions to understand the customer scenario, or directly provide a structured explanation. This was not explained or demonstrated in the training content.

As a result, I was unable to perform effectively in the assessment and lost one certification attempt. This is concerning, as it represents not only the loss of an exam attempt, but also the significant time and effort invested in preparation based on the existing learning materials.

I fully understand and appreciate the intention behind scenario-based assessments. However, if the exam format has changed so substantially, the learning journeys and preparation guidance should also be updated to clearly explain expectations, structure, and evaluation criteria.

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Foundational SAP Notes for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
@Stephan_Heinberg Hi Stephan,

The code split between SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and Private Cloud Edition (PCE) follows SAP’s S/4HANA Compatibility Scope Matrix, which defines which parts of the on-premise code line are consumable in PCE.

  • S4PEXT 109 contains the backend ABAP layer specific to PCE, including cloud-compatible extensions.

  • UIS4PEXT 109 contains the Fiori frontend content aligned with the PCE scope.

We have summarized the functional differences here in this blog by @jmarquezmr 
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/functional-differences-between-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-and-sap-s/ba-p/13568237

Regards,
Setu

entry.title: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content:
Several people have reached out to me this week to describe the new way you set up document grounding with Joule Studio. So here goes.

What is Document Grounding

Many of you may know about Document Grounding, but for those who don't here's a very brief explanation.

  1. The basic way we use AI is to send a prompt to an LLM (a set of "indexed" information).
  2. If we want the LLM to take into account additional information it may not have, we can provide "context" (though the amount of "context" you are allowed to send may be constrained).

One of those pieces of context may come from a set of documents (e.g., housed in SharePoint or in the SAP BTP Object Store service). In order to use those documents as context we must perform Document Grounding, which takes the documents, "chunks" them into small pieces, and then "embeds" them so they can be used as context in our AI requests.

In Joule Studio, when we create agents, we essentially specify an LLM to handle specific types of prompts, and then provide context and instructions for what we want the agent to do.

The "Old" Way in Joule Studio

The old way we performed Document Grounding in Joule Studio was to go into AI Core and create a resource group, connect that resource group to a content store (e.g., the place we store the documents), and have AI Core chunk and embed the documents so we could use the content within an agent or for use when sending a prompt to AI Core. Joule Studio would be configured to connect with a specific AI Core, and the developer of an agent would type in the name of a resource group in AI Core to use with their agent.

Here we can see in the SAP AI Launchpad that we are connected to the "dbw" resource, and we have created a "pipeline" with documents.

If we click inside, we can see that this pipeline has 4 documents, each chunked and embedded. 

But doing this required going into the SAP AI Launchpad, creating Generic Secrets by encoding credentials in Base64, and several more steps in tools we may not be familiar with.

Joule Studio still makes use of the same mechanism in AI Core, but now takes care of creating all the artifacts behind the scene (and enables some new capabilities).  

 

1. Prerequisites

You need an instance of SAP AI Core and an S3-compatible document store such as the Object Store service in BTP. I won't go into setting these up, but you can find out more information here:

  • AI Core
  • Object Store

If you need more information, leave a comment.

Note you can define many instances of AI Core and Object Store to be used with Joule Studio.

 

2. Destinations

You need to set up destinations to AI Core and Object Store on both your SAP Build tenant and your Joule tenant. 

AI Core Destination

Get the service key of your AI Core instance, and create a destination as shown below.

Append /oauth/token to the url value of the service key and use this for the destination's Token Service URL.

Add the additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-ai-core and set it to true. This makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

Object Store Destination

Similarly, get the service key for the object store service instance and set the following destination fields with the corresponding service field value:

Destination FieldService Key Field
URLaccess_key_id
Client IDhost (add https://)
Client Secretsecret_access_key
Token Service URLhost (add https://)

Add the following additional properties:

Additional PropertyValue
regionregion value from service key
bucketbucket value from service key
usernameusername value from service key
typeS3
sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store
true

The additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

3. Set Up in Control Tower

In the Control Tower, the SAP Build admin will decide:

  • From which object stores to create Document Grounding.
  • In which AI Core instances to create these Document Grounding pipelines.

The Control Tower now has a Joule section, including a Document Grounding tile so the admin can create Document Grounding and make it available to Joule Studio developers.

Click the Document Grounding tile. You can now create sets of Document Grounding.

Note that while in the SAP AI Launchpad you could create different pipelines with different sets of documents in the same resource group, here each object store will create a separate resource group.

Click Add.

Give the resource group a name.

Select the AI Core instance in which to create the resource group.

And finally select the object store whose documents you want to ground.

Click Add.

The status of the resource group will be Pending. 

After about a minute (depending on the size of the documents), the status will change to Completed.

(Early on, I occasionally got Error messages, or Pending simply remained for a long time, and sometimes they would alternate between those messages. In such cases, make sure the destinations are configured properly and make sure the documents in the Object Store are not corrupted.)

If you now look in SAP AI Launchpad, and go to SAP AI Core Administration > Resource Groups, you will see a new resource group whose name is the name you specified (without spaces) with a Unix timestamp appended.

Though the resource group should immediately appear on the Resource Groups page, it may take a few extra minutes for the resource group to appear on the Workspaces page. 

Once it does, you can select it and see the pipeline and Document Grounding inside the resource group. 

 

4. Add Document Grounding to Your Agent 

Now that the admin has set up a resource group and triggered the document grounding for a set of documents, developers of Joule Studio agents can use them in their agents.

Inside an agent, the developer can specify tools, including documents. Select Add Tools > Documents.

This opens a dialogue to specify which resource group created by the admin to use. Specify a name for the documents (as seen in the agent) and a description to help the agent know when to use them.

Then select from among the resource groups created by the admin.

Advantages

The advantages of this method are:

  • Admins and developers no longer have to work in AI Launchpad, including creating Generic Secrets and dealing with Base64 encoding of credentials.
  • Admins decide what document grounding gets used in Joule Studio agents.
    • From the look of the UI, admins will eventually be able to assign a resource group to a specific environment, giving admins even more control
  • Developers have a predefined set of  resource groups to choose from, using a dropdown list.
  • More than one AI Core instance and more than one Object Store instance can be used to define document grounding for a Joule Studio.

Note that this method creates a single document grounding pipeline in each resource group it creates; using AI Launchpad, you can create multiple pipelines in a single resource group.

There may be more advantages and limitations. Please add a comment with your opinion about this feature, or anything I missed.

entry.title: Mastering Filtering and Search Capabilities in SAP Fiori Elements for OData V4
entry.content:
What does the filter bar do in SAP Fiori elements?

The filter bar is the primary component for data filtering in SAP Fiori elements applications. It appears at the top of list report page applications and provides users with an intuitive interface to narrow down large datasets.

Key SAP Fiori elements filter bar features

  1. Automatic Generation: The filter bar is automatically generated based on your OData service metadata.
  2. Annotation-Driven: Control visibility, default values, and behavior through Core Data Services (CDS) annotations.
  3. Responsive Design: Adapts seamlessly to different screen sizes and devices.
  4. Value Help Integration: Provides dropdown lists and value help dialogs for easier data selection.
  5. Semantic Date Support: Automatic support for semantic dates like TODAY, First Day Of Week, Year To Date,….
  6. Visual Filters: Support for filtering based on measure values – for example, selecting supplier based on supplier rating or plant based on revenue.
  7. Filter Bar as a Building Block: Readily consumable in a custom page. See The FilterBar Building Block topic for more information.
  8. Leveraging AI: Allows users to submit complex queries using natural language (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition only as of January 2026)

These features are covered in-depth in the official documentation – Configuring Filter Bars.

 

What’s in this blog for you?

I don’t intend to repeat here what is already well detailed out in the SAP Help Portal documentation.  

What I want to address in this article are some details of the search capability, along with a few lesser-known features such as support for the Clear button, custom filters, and the impact of including a filter field from a navigation entity on the query.

And, of course, how the filter bar can leverage AI capabilities.

 

How does the filter bar support search?

The filter bar, by default, includes a search bar. This will not come up if the underlying entity does not support the search capability (i.e., your entity is annotated with a SearchRestriction where Searchable=false).

A common misconception is that SAP Fiori elements controls search behavior like wildcards or fuzzy matching. In reality, SAP Fiori elements simply passes the user's search string to the back end via the $search parameter. The back end determines how to interpret and process this string.

Debugging Tip: If search isn't behaving as expected, check the network trace to verify the search string is being passed correctly. This helps identify whether the issue lies with the front-end or back-end implementation.

So next time your search is not working as expected, you are expected to raise a ticket to the right component rather than SAP Fiori elements  🙂

One exception: There are a few characters that SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 ignores and does not pass to the back end. These are listed in our documentation: Enabling the Search Function.

 

How does the Clear button work in SAP Fiori elements?

Many applications would love to have a “Clear” button to remove all selections with a single click. The way to do it now is for the user to manually clear out the values from each and every filter field. For an usage scenario that requires regular clearing of all filter values before new ones are applied, this is both time-consuming and poor user experience.

SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 allows exactly this – the ability to clear all filter fields with a single click. For more details, see the V4-specific section "Adding a Clear Button” of Adapting the Filter Bar. It even allows application developers to add some custom logic when the clear is invoked - via the onAfterClear() controller extension method.

 

How does filtering on a filter field from a navigation entity work in SAP Fiori elements?

As detailed out in the page Adapting the Filter Bar, the filter bar in the list report page supports filter fields coming from the navigation entity, both 1:1 as well as 1:n navigation entities. When a value is added to such a field, the main entity records having at least one navigation entity record with the given value for the filter field from the navigation entity are part of the result set – the rest are filtered out. So far, so good 🙂

Handling of multiple fields from a navigation entity

Now, consider a use case where you want to filter on the main entity records (“Travel”) with several filters applied on fields from the navigation entity (“_Passenger”). Let’s say you want to roll out a special discount for all “Lufthansa” travels that had at least one >60, female as a passenger.

Expected Result: Travels with passengers who are BOTH female AND over 60

Here’s how you would go about adding filter values:

  • Travel.Carrier (=”Lufthansa”)
  • Travel._Passenger.Age (>60 years)
  • Travel._Passenger.Gender (=”Female”)

Once the query runs though, you are in for a slightly unpleasant surprise!

Actual Result: Travels with (any female passenger) AND (any passenger over 60)

Why does this happen?

The reason is that SAP Fiori elements combines each filter field with an AND operator. This works fine with main entity filter fields but when there are multiple filter fields from a navigation entity, the regular and routine AND handling leads to a result that is a bit counter intuitive.

Current Query Generated:

$filter=Carrier eq 'Lufthansa'  

       and _Passenger/any(L1:L1/Age ge 60)  

       and _Passenger/any(L1:L1/Gender eq 'F')

 This leads to all “Lufthansa” travel records that have at least one passenger above 60 years and at least one passenger of female gender. Note that the passenger record that matches the “above 60 years” and the passenger record that matches the female gender may not be the same here.

The expected query that matches the intended outcome would have been:

$filter=Carrier eq 'Lufthansa'

     and _Passenger/any(L1:L1/Age ge 60 and L1/Gender eq 'F')

Possible workaround

One option could be to make use of custom filters to achieve this – this is quite some effort and needs careful consideration (see next few sections). Another potential way out would be to enable use of the AI-assisted easy filter feature, detailed in the next section, once it is enhanced to handle such complex queries.

 

How does SAP Fiori elements leverage AI capabilities?

The AI-Assisted Easy Filter is one of the “base” i.e., non-premium AI features offered by SAP Fiori elements – but ONLY for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition offering at the moment.

It allows users to query via natural language, which is way more intuitive and easier than filling each filter field manually. This has big potential to save time, since the end user needs to only query in natural language and the framework takes the onus of breaking down the complex conditions into the required $filter query.

No commitment but the rumour out there is that there are plans to enhance it with the ability to handle complex queries like the one in the Travel & Passenger example above 🙂

Watch AI-Assisted Easy Filter Demo

 

When to use custom filters in SAP Fiori elements?

By default, all filterable fields of the main entity are shown in the filter bar of the list report page. One filter field = one filterable property. And one simple condition using any of the standard operators (=, >=, <=, between, contains, startsWith,… and so on) depending on the filter field configuration – Configuring Filter Fields talks more about the various filter restrictions that one can set.

But what if you need a much more complex condition than what we offer by default? SAP Fiori elements allows applications to add their own custom filters. This can be useful in two scenarios:

  1. When you need a different -presumably better- visualization for the filter field. For instance, you would like something closer to a rating indicator rather than a dropdown showing different values for a rating filter.
  2. You need a more complex condition – like those mentioned under the V4-specific section “Custom Filters with Custom Operators” of Adding Custom Fields to the Filter Bar page.

Important: When defining custom filters with multiple properties, ensure proper handling of filter conditions to avoid unexpected query behavior. The documentation provides detailed guidelines for common pitfalls.

If you choose to add the custom filter fields, consider using the SAP Fiori tools – Application Modeler extension to generate the fragment and handler files and automatically register them in the manifest so that appears at the desired position in the filter bar. You can then focus on the intended logic by substituting the placeholder content in the fragment file with your own code.

 

5 steps to optimizing filtering capabilities in SAP Fiori elements

SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 provides comprehensive filtering and search capabilities that significantly enhance user productivity and application performance. By understanding and properly implementing these features, developers can create intuitive, efficient applications that meet business needs while minimizing custom code.

The key to success lies in:

  • Leveraging metadata-driven annotations
  • Implementing performance-optimized filters when implementing your own conditions via custom filters
  • Creating user-friendly filter layouts when creating your own UI fragments for custom filters
  • Testing with realistic data volumes
  • Following SAP Fiori design guidelines

Whether you're building a simple list report page or a complex analytical application, mastering these filtering and search techniques will help you deliver applications that users love and that perform efficiently at scale.

 

Additional Resources

  • SAP Fiori Design Guidelines: https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design/
  • SAPUI5 SDK: https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/ 
  • SAP Fiori development portal: https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/test-resources/sap/fe/core/fpmExplorer/index.html#/topic/introducti...
  • SAP Community: https://community.sap.com/topics/ui5 
  • OData V4 Specification: https://www.odata.org/documentation/

entry.title: Chapter 2 || SAP Joule: Interaction Patterns of SAP Joule
entry.content:
SAP Joule Series:
Chapter 1 || SAP Joule: The central nervous system for Business
Chapter 2 || SAP Joule: Interaction Patterns of SAP Joule

Joule Capabilities are categorized into different Interaction patterns.

1. Informational Interaction Pattern:

The informational pattern provides knowledge-based results. These are, for example, policy-related questions. This can be based on SAP-owned content, such as SAP Help Pages, or could be a customer-owned content as well, by integrating the SAP Document Grounding services with Joule.

 

 

2. Navigational Interaction Pattern:

Joule makes it easy for users to reach the right SAP application or screen, so they can manage business processes on their own. With Joule, users can jump straight to what they need, which is ideal for those who aren’t familiar with SAP’s navigation.

 

3. Transactional Interaction Pattern

Joule gives users a direct entry point to access SAP’s backend systems. They can start and manage business processes just by using natural language and generative AI. For example, reviewing and approving purchase orders, creating new job postings, or handling any other create, read, update, or delete tasks. All the SAP's cloud products are now building content packages for Joule to support the most essential interactions for the users.

 

4. Analytical Interaction Pattern

This pattern aims to provides insights and data analysis capabilities. Users can ask questions related to business metrics, trends, and performance indicators, and Joule will provide relevant insights from the SAP Analytics Cloud system.

entry.title: Re: store credentials for destination in MTA file
entry.content: Don't create backend destinations via the mta but create them manually through the BTP Cockpit. Such credentials could get rotated (change of password) and/or shared with other apps needing access to the same backend, so best maintain them centrally (BTP Cockpit) instead of specifying them in a single app's mta.

entry.title: Re: Getting error when opening excel file using GUI download
entry.content: This issue typically occurs because the Excel file generated via SAP GUI Download contains structural inconsistencies that newer Excel versions validate more strictly. When Excel detects unreadable or invalid XML content (often related to PivotTables, formatting, or internal relationships), it triggers a repair process on open, which can result in removed or broken components. This is not strictly an SAP issue but an Excel compatibility and validation problem. A common workaround is to keep the export as a simple flat table and avoid complex Excel features in the generated file, or rebuild those features after download. If the file is already impacted and Excel’s built-in repair is not sufficient, repairing the workbook structure using a third party tools like Stellar Repair for Excel can help restore the file and prevent further crashes or data loss.

entry.title: Re: Cloud Integration - JMS Queue - Entries Number
entry.content:
Hola Fellipe,

I hope I'm not off topic, but I'm certainly late.

I've just struggled with something similar, especially since when SAP brought back the good old "pipeline" concept, belonging to SAP PI/PO and missing in Integration Suite.

First of all, you can find all answers by calling this: https://<your-btp-host>/api/v1/$metadata (see attached).

Then, the "right" entity is simply Queues, not JmsQueue, which doesn't exist and comes back with a 501 HTTP response, bad. The response (ATOM) is quite detailed (see attached).

Then you can drill down: https://<your-btp-host>/api/v1/Queues('YourQueueName')/Messages

In the response you should  (haven't tried it yet) find 

  • Msgid

  • Failed: boolean (true o false).

    If you wanna get rid of failed messages:

     

    • Method: DELETE

    • URL:

      Plaintext
      https://<your-btp-host>/api/v1/JmsMessages(Msgid='MSG_ID',Name='YourQueueName',Failed=true)
       
      If you want to reprocess (push) the failed msg, sorry: I still need to investigate but I have a feeling that a bridge http->jms  iFlow could be necessary (given it's a HTTP POST).
       
      Hope this helps. You and the Community.
       
      BR
       
      Alex
